metadata.case_name: Manager, Sree Krishna Oil Mills v. State (Kharagpore Municipality)

facts.text: Appellant is the Manager of Sree Krishna Oil Mills, Midnapore, proprietor Srilal Bajoria. Both tried jointly for offence under S. 7/16A(i) of Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954. Proprietor acquitted, appellant sentenced to one year rigorous imprisonment.
On July 10, 1964, at about 11 A.M., appellant going in truck carrying 100 tins of mustard oil, stopped by Food Inspector, Kharagpore Municipality.

Appellant informed Food Inspector that oil manufactured at Sree Krishna Oil Mills, Midnapore. Food Inspector suspected adulteration, took three samples per Act: one to Public Analyst, one kept himself, one to appellant.
Public Analyst report dated August 5, 1964: saponification value 181.6, Iodine value 107.2, B.R. reading at 40C 60.1. Opined sample adulterated (Ext. 5).
Sanction for prosecution obtained from Chairman of Municipality, Shri K.C. Chaki, on August 19, 1964.
Appellant prosecuted before Magistrate, 1st Class, Midnapore. Pleaded not guilty, convicted on evidence and Public Analyst report, sentenced to one year RI.
Revision before Calcutta High Court dismissed on December 24, 1968.
Municipality resolution dated July 28, 1960 authorised Chairman to perform functions and exercise powers of Local Authority under Prevention of Food Adulteration Act (Ext. 7).
Fresh election of Chairman held after 1960 resolution; Shri K.C. Chaki was new Chairman.
Appellant sought to adduce additional evidence of Municipality resolution dated August 18, 1965, giving fresh authorisation to Chairman.
Appellant on bail since 1964 for nearly seven years.

legal_issues.text: Whether the sanction for prosecution was valid and legal.
Whether the report of the Public Analyst was a proper report in law and could form basis of conviction.
Whether Public Analyst's report was bad and incomplete for failure to carry out all tests under A.17.06 of Appendix B to Rules and disclose data.

petitioner_arguments.text: Sanction invalid as Chairman did not apply mind; not granted by Local Authority (Municipality); new Chairman cannot use 1960 resolution post fresh elections.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: S. 20 Prevention of Food Adulteration Act; Bengal Municipal Act S.51

petitioner_arguments.text: Public Analyst report not proper/complete: only 3 out of 7 tests under A.17.06 Appendix B; no basis/data for conclusion of adulteration.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: A.17.06 Appendix B Prevention of Food Adulteration Rules, 1955

petitioner_arguments.text: Standards in A.17.06 not conclusive as mustard oil can yield higher readings in some places.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Technical books; Jagadish Chandra Jain v. Corporation of Calcutta; Netai Chandra v. Corporation of Calcutta; In re Perumal Co.

petitioner_arguments.text: Sentence harsh for first offender; prosecution prior to amendment imposing minimum sentence.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: S.16(1) Prevention of Food Adulteration Act (unamended)

respondent_arguments.text: Sanction valid under S.51 Bengal Municipal Act and 1960 resolution; applies to any Chairman for time being; Municipality has perpetual succession.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: S.51, S.15(2) Bengal Municipal Act; S.20 Prevention of Food Adulteration Act

respondent_arguments.text: Public Analyst report sufficient even if not all tests done; saponification test failure alone proves adulteration.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: A.17.06 Appendix B; S.13(5) Prevention of Food Adulteration Act

court_reasoning.text: Challenge to sanction misconceived; Chairman authorised by 1960 resolution (general power to any Chairman); fresh elections do not deprive new Chairman; 1965 resolution post-sanction does not invalidate.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Municipality body corporate with perpetual succession; authorisation continues unless rescinded.

court_reasoning.text: Public Analyst report effective despite omission of four tests; saponification test failure alone renders sample adulterated.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Even assuming other tests normal, non-conformity in one test suffices.

court_reasoning.text: Standards in Appendix B binding, made after consultation with Central Committee; cannot be varied by technical books or decisions; appellant could have sought CFL certificate to supersede.
court_reasoning.key_observation: S.3, S.23(1)(b) Act empower standards; S.2(i)(a) defines adulteration.

court_reasoning.text: Sentence modified considering bail period, first offence, proprietor acquitted, oil nearly met standards.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Offences antisocial but facts warrant reduction to 2 months RI and Rs.1000 fine.

holdings.text: Sanction valid; report admissible and proves adulteration.
Standards in Appendix B conclusive; one failed test suffices for adulteration.
Sentence reduced to 2 months RI and fine Rs.1000 (default 1 month RI).

precedents_cited.case_name: Jagadish Chandra Jain v. Corporation of Calcutta
precedents_cited.relevance: Cited by appellant for variable mustard oil standards; court did not allow to vary rules.

precedents_cited.case_name: Netai Chandra and Surendra Nath Dey v. Corporation of Calcutta
precedents_cited.relevance: Cited by appellant for variable mustard oil standards.
Cited by appellant for variable mustard oil standards.

precedents_cited.case_name: Andhra Pradesh Grain and Seed Merchants Association v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Standards prescribed after expert consultation binding on dealers.

statutes_cited.name: Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines adulteration, empowers standards in rules, admissibility of analyst report, minimum sentences post-amendment, sanction requirement.

statutes_cited.name: Prevention of Food Adulteration Rules, 1955
statutes_cited.relevance: Prescribes mustard oil standards; failure in saponification test proves adulteration.

statutes_cited.name: Bengal Municipal Act, 1932
statutes_cited.relevance: Chairman exercises powers of Commissioners/Local Authority; perpetual succession.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for certificate appeal to Supreme Court.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed subject to modification of sentence from one year RI to two months RI and fine of Rs. 1,000/- (in default one month RI). Criminal Miscellaneous Petitions for additional evidence dismissed.

key_quotes.text: Omission to report on the other four tests does not, in our view make the report ineffective or the report inconclusive.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Holds single test failure sufficient for adulteration.

key_quotes.text: standards having been fixed as aforesaid any person who deals in articles of food which do not conform to them contravenes the provisions of the Act.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: offences for adulteration of food must be severely dealt with, no doubt depending on the facts of each case.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Justifies sentence reduction based on facts.
